channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Technology & The Great War
channel.desc: Military history professor Richard Faulkner discusses the technological changes that occurred in the late 19th and early 20th centuries that led to the development of new weapons deployed during World War I.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Thomas Maier, The Invisible Spy
channel.desc: Investigative reporter Thomas Maier profiles former NFL football player and World War II spy Ernest Cuneo, and his connection to British Prime Minister Winston Churchill's New York-based spy ring during the war.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Frank Lavin, Inside the Reagan White House
channel.desc: Frank Lavin talks about his experiences while serving on the National Security Council and the White House staff during the Reagan administration.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Leah Sottile, Blazing Eye Sees All - Love Has Won, False Prophets, and the Fever Dream of the American New Age
channel.desc: Leah Sottile tracks the rise of New Age spiritual movements and their influence on America. Powell's Books in Portland, Oregon, hosted this event.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: After Words
channel.desc: Atlantic Magazine staff writer Sophie Gilbert looks at pop culture of the '90s & early 2000s and its impact on women and the feminist movement.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Benjamin Nathans, To the Success of Our Hopeless Cause
channel.desc: University of Pennsylvania professor Benjamin Nathans talks about the Soviet dissident movement and its role in the collapse of the Soviet Union.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: The Civil War
channel.desc: Carnegie Mellon University professor Edda Fields-Black talks about Harriet Tubman's role in the 1863 Combahee River Raid, a secret military mission against Confederates in South Carolina which rescued over 700 former slaves.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Kathleen Duval, Native Nations
channel.desc: History professor Kathleen Duval chronicles the history and power of Native nations before and after the colonization of North America.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Kathleen deLaski, Who Needs College Anymore?
channel.desc: Education Design Lab founder Kathleen deLaski examines whether the U.S. higher education system can meet the needs of future generations of students.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Dr. Robert Smith, Has Medicine Lost Its Mind?
channel.desc: Dr. Robert Smith argues that the medical establishment has failed to consider the importance of mental health in favor of focusing on physical health. Seminary Co-op in Chicago hosted this event.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Adam Gussow, My Family & I
channel.desc: University of Mississippi professor and musician Adam Gussow shares his experiences being in an interracial family in Mississippi before and after the rise of the Black Lives Matter movement.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Michele Filgate, What My Mother and I Don't Talk About
channel.desc: Literary Hub editor Michele Filgate discusses stories of sexual assault and domestic abuse through a collection of essays written by 15 authors.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: After Words
channel.desc: Journalist Rebecca Grant reports on maternal health care in the U.S. and discusses how social and political dynamics impact pregnancy and motherhood.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US
channel.title: Kim Heckler, A Woman of Firsts
channel.desc: Kimberly Heckler talks about her biography of her mother, Margaret Heckler, a trailblazing Republican member of Congress from Massachusetts (1967-83), who later served as HUD Secretary and Ambassador to Ireland under Presidents Reagan and Bush.

channel.name: CSPAN 2 US

channel.desc: Frank Lavin talks about his experiences while serving on the National Security Council and the White House staff during the Reagan administration.
